instruction: What metric was chosen to validate the models' performance in forecasting submarine landslide susceptibility, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to validate the models' performance in forecasting submarine landslide susceptibility was a combination of internal metrics (Calinski-Harabasz index, silhouette index, and Davies-Bouldin index) and external metrics (existing landslide distribution, hydrodynamic distribution, and liquefaction distribution). These metrics were used to assess the goodness-of-fit and accuracy of the models.

The extent to which these metrics can go in evaluating the models' performance depends on the specific context and requirements of the study. These metrics provide quantitative measures of the models' performance based on different aspects such as data features, environmental variables, and distribution patterns. They can provide valuable insights into the models' effectiveness in predicting submarine landslide susceptibility.

instruction: What unsupervised machine learning models were used in the analysis of submarine landslide susceptibility and how were their performances compared?
Output: The unsupervised machine learning models used in the analysis of submarine landslide susceptibility were k-means, spectral clustering, and hierarchical clustering. The performances of these models were compared by evaluating their goodness-of-fit and accuracy using both internal metrics (Calinski-Harabasz index, silhouette index, and Davies-Bouldin index) and external metrics (existing landslide distribution, hydrodynamic distribution, and liquefaction distribution). The findings showed that all three models performed commendably and accurately in forecasting the submarine landslide susceptibility. However, spectral clustering demonstrated the greatest congruence with environmental geology parameters, indicating that it performed the best among the three models.
